comments.text:
Jensen Huang was right — “it would be impossible without artificial intelligence.” The GPU industry has hit a technological wall. Maintaining high frame rates with increasingly smaller and more efficient components is becoming economically unsustainable. The traditional path — raw performance scaling — no longer makes sense. NVIDIA fully understands this.

AMD still seems to miss the point. Upscaling is not the same as machine learning-based solutions like DLSS. Without AI support, FSR has clear limitations and will inevitably fall behind.

People are now accusing NVIDIA of deception — claiming it’s all just marketing, that the new 12VHPWR connectors are a ploy to force hardware upgrades. Maybe that’s true. Maybe it’s just strategy. But it doesn’t matter anymore.

The core truth is this: the future of image processing is driven by machine learning. There’s no turning back. Whether DLSS is marketing or not is irrelevant — it’s the only viable path forward.

comments.text:
And this whole shebang is exactly why my 3080Ti still earns its keep contentedly. It's unfortunate that NVidia seems to be so heavily invested in the AI biz that the gaming GPU market has degraded so much. I will say one thing about the consumer end though. Because many people want the latest and greatest (sorta), they're willing to drop perfectly good hardware, even for a terrible price. Sure, my 3080Ti can't handle some new games with max RT and graphics, but I can run some RT and high graphics at 4k. On the competitive end, I can generate 144+ FPS if I want to, which is more than enough. Factor in that my card is three generations old and can be picked up used for below MSRP, and in my opinion the 5070 and even the 5080 lose any attraction they ever had.

5070: "I can match the 4090 in performance."
3080Ti: "Maybe, but old geezers like me are still kicking your rear end for prices that you will never get down to."

comments.text:
These GPUs should no longer be considered a new generation, they are just "40-series Plus" GPUs. (5070 = 4070 Super Plus/5080 = 4080 Super Plus/5090 = 4090 Super) 

This is because they offer either identical performance to their 40 series counter parts, have performance uplift identical to their raw resource uplift (5090 has 30% more RAM/Power Draw/CUDA Cores and unsurprisingly exactly 30% more performance than the 4090). GDDR7 and the new AI features aren't enough to justify calling them 50 series cards, cause everything else is basically the same.

Nvidia has done this in the past where a new generation was made on the same architecture, but the last time they did this was in 2013 with the 600 series and I can't find information on how well/poorly that was received. Nvidia hasn't been doing this for over a decade and it should have stayed that way, people got used to performance uplifts with each new generation and the 50 series just doesn't do anything new.

These GPUs should never have been called the 50 series.

comments.text:
I don't really mind fake frames as long as I don't see/notice it. I tried Cyperpunk with DLSS on, basically providing me with stable "60 fps" on ultra settings. 
I still play on native 1920x1080 so I'm not looking to compare with people looking for 60 fps on 2K or 4K.
I've seen videos where the same card was tested and the reviewer was complaining about massive delay with DLSS on but I never noticed it, so it can't really bother me... And I'm wondering if the delay get worse if you try to run in higher resolutions. But for a native 1920x1080 user who just wants to play the highest settings in the game, the DLSS technology actually works fine. I think sometimes the loudest people are just techies who is testing the performance on 2K-4K range, which is actually still not many games that use.
Peopke make fun of AI generated frames but I bet we will see a whole lot of this improved and moved into console gaming drastically. 

4060 ti 16 gb RAM - (yes yes, but it's actually quite a good card with the extra RAM on it)

comments.text:
I work as a lead mechanical design engineer where I design products with very powerful FPGAs. 

I design custom cooling solutions and design program curves that control the system fans based on temperature. 

These days, top of the line silicon is happy at 80c. Modern silicon not too long ago had a 85c thermal cap - today it's 100c. 

Hot? Yeah. So what - these things will live a LONG life at 80c. When you allow the chip to be hotter, you dramatically reduce cooling noise.

I aim for 80c+ on the die because sound is major concern. Nothing wrong with cards running hot on new cards in an effort to be more quiet for the guy playing on it. 

This is improvement :) Hot dies and quiet computers.

"We removed 15% of Blackwell cores from the 4070 Super to the 5070 Ti, use a significantly smaller die on our previous gen well established high-yield process, undoubtedly cutting our production costs by at least 50% over early production yield 4070's. You're lucky we were even willing to take 2% of our worst binning cut-down Blackwell silicon to put into a few GPU's we will trickle into the marketplace, especially since we have roundabout ways to sell those GPU's into China who are willing to pay such a huge premium over US corporations price, even for GPU silicon where 5 years ago we would have taken a poor yield GA100 and cut it down into multiple GA107 RTX 3050 mobile chips, now we can simply repackage a poor yield GB200 or GB202 into China products 70% as powerful while still making the same or more gross profit per unit."

I don't understand the people who want a bajillion FPS.. I don't see a difference between lower and higher framerates.. as long as the game runs smoothly, as in, the framerate is consistent, I don't give a shit. Sure, some games run amazingly but they're so badly optimized you get framedrops all over the place.. I would rather have lower consistant rate than super high at times, and then lag spikes at the worst moments possible. At least with lower consistant rates, my inputs will also be consistant. 
That being said I want decent framerate that doesn't look slugging all the time either. I just don't need 250 FPS or whatever.. 30 to 60 is fine for me. You don't even notice it after 2 minutes of gameplay. (heck I'd have to check how many FPS I get on Horizon Zero Dawn.. game i've been playing lately.. cause it runs super well with every option maxed out.. and then there were the first two Spiderman games.. 1 and Miles Morales.. that ran well.. when they did.. then gave me lag spikes at the worst moments possible, even with everything at the lowest setting possible..)
EDIT: just checked, Horizon runs flawlessly at 60, was already going to play it after watching this video haha

comments.text:
I think this frame gen needs some time to mature. In the future with proper game engine utilization it could be huge. Right now it’s a closed loop. That’s why the latency is bad, it still has to wait for the engine to confirm yes that’s where you should be, or where that should be. Which is why you get the shimmering. AI frame says this, then real frame based on game engine says nope, I’m still over here bro. But imagine an engine that can get updated by the GPU on where it says things currently are. It has potential, but right now, it’s kind of meh. Kind of like DLSS and RT was 6 years ago, but look at it now.

I’m not saying buy it, if you can find a used 4070S for less than go that way, or a 4080. But it doesn’t seem like the market is letting those go for much cheaper, it’s really dollars per TOPs out there, like the mining days.

comments.text: So if there is a low-profile single-slot version of this card, it might actually be decent, as it is though, it might be the most ridiculous/pointless GPU of all time, I'm not sure how the thing could be much worse tbh, also, gamers tend to care about gameplay, that is how good & fun a game feels to play, and fake frames absolutely destroy gameplay quality, even just a small percentage of A.I. frame interpolation introduces significant latency, thus really lowering the input-fidelity, in otherworlds degrading the gameplay quality, and making the game much less fun in return, which is the opposite of what your average gamer wants, anyway, this could be an amazing low-profile GPU, stick an all solid copper heatsink on it and some vapour chamber pipes, and two decent small fans, maybe even all metal fans to help keep the footprint small and keep temps low, one of them sucking air inwards, and the other extracting the spent warm air out immediately, ideally pulling the fresh air inwards from a vent in the side panel, maybe even with a duct/tunnel to make sure it's air from outside the case, then as I said immediately extracted through & out, should keep the copper+pipes nice and cool.

comments.text: There is actually a pretty amazing little low-profile SKU of the RTX4060, stick it in a 100 dollar second hand i7 9700K mini PC with a cheap 64GB RAM kit (or even 128GB), grab an Intel 3DX m.2 Drive and install Win10 X-Lite, turn half your RAM into a RAMDISK for games and emulators, and you have yourself a tiny little gaming powerhouse to stick under your TV or wherever you like, thanks to the Intel 3DX drive & RAMDISK, you will have an incredibly low-latency PC, for super snappy games and performance, and make use of Nvidia's immaculate integer-scaling, for running games at a base res of 540p, to 4K, with very little fidelity loss, yet you get 4X the FPS, on a 4K TV viewed from a good 1 meter or more away, it will look indistinguishable from native 4K, even close up on a 4K monitor, 540p integer-scaled to 4K look really nice, especially on an OLED monitor, and that 400% increase in FPS will mean really nice frame-times and superb 1% frames, even for a 480Hz/FPS OLED monitor, and because integer-scaling is a native rendering method, you get no added latency or artifacts, just nice consistent frame-pacing with crispy looking natively rendered frames.

comments.text:
4070 super has over 7000 cuda cores, more Render output cores, and more Ray Tracing cores. In previous testing of the 5090, the difference in performance over the 4090 was relative to the more cores it had. So based on that, I could have already guessed that the performance of the 5070 would have similar or even less raster performance as the 4070 super. 

This is why when the 5090 reviews hit, over night all new Nvidia GPUs from the 4000 series save the 4060 was sold out and being scalped.

As far as AMD. I wouldn’t hold my breath because I doubt the raw raster performance will match that 7900 XT. I suspect that Ray Tracing will finally match that of RTX 4070 Super for the 9070 XT variant and 4070 on the base 9070 variant.  I have a funny feeling that the 40% uplift is based on frame gen and not real frames.  

With inflation the way it is, the rising cost of production, and new tariffs. The 550 dollars of 2025 is probably worth like $300 back when the RTX 3000 series released. So the fact is that they are priced accordingly. Thus a 5070 and 9070 would feel like entry level card launch. 

People can’t measure prices the same as before and it will only get worse and not better.

comments.text:
Scene: Obi Jesen Kenobi, clad in a black leather jacket with a glowing green aura, stands before the gathered tech enthusiasts. A slight smirk curls his lips as he addresses the crowd, hands gesturing like a maestro conducting the symphony of silicon.

Jensen Kenobi: "So, what I told you was true… from a certain point of view."

The audience stirs. A lone gamer in the back raises a hand, skeptical.

Gamer: "From a certain point of view?! You said the RTX 5070 was as fast as the RTX 4090! That's not a point of view! That's... marketing wizardry!"

Jensen Kenobi's smirk deepens. His jacket gleams with a kind of Force-infused ray tracing magic.

Jensen Kenobi: "Ah, my young tech enthusiast, you'll find that many of the truths we cling to depend greatly on our... frame rates. When I said ‘as fast,’ I didn’t mean it in the mundane, linear sense that you mortals might calculate on traditional benchmarks. No, I spoke of the grander vision, the essence of speed. Perhaps it’s the speed of accessibility. Or the speed of innovation. Or the speed... of a clever marketing department."

He paces slowly, hands clasped behind his back, as if conjuring visions of DLSS-enhanced dreams.

Jensen Kenobi: "You see, the RTX 5070 may not wield the raw, unbridled power of the 4090, but with DLSS, the Force of AI itself, it reaches heights you never thought possible. To truly understand its speed is to let go of your preconceptions... your benchmarks... your need for consistent definitions of truth. That, my friends, is the NVIDIA way."

He pauses, gesturing grandly toward a holographic chart that conveniently lacks any hard numbers.

Jensen Kenobi: "So, yes, the 5070 is as fast as the 4090... from a certain point of view. And isn’t that the point that really matters?"

The room falls into a contemplative silence as Jensen Kenobi turns to exit, his leather jacket billowing dramatically behind him, as if propelled by an invisible GPU fan.

comments.text:
@ I wasn't comparing 90fps to 120fps, I was talking about multi-frame generation applied to 30-45fps experience to 90fps or 120fps, where 90 or 120fps may look smooth but will not feel as responsive.

Reflex is a better tool if the base frame rate is also higher, but depending on the game, and particularly with newer games, the heavy demand on a 70 card like this or a 60 card in the future using multi frame generation as a crutch to achieve high frame rates from a low base frame rate will not be solved by reflex alone.

Games will also make this worse, with Monster Hunter Wilds starting a horrible precedent of using frame generation to define their requirements charts with no accounting for the negatives of interpolating so many frames in between the actual game engine frames.

And the biggest and most obvious elephant in the room, if these technologies alone absolutely yield a near enough experience, why are all those that are jacking up used 4090 prices buying those instead of a nice new 5070 with "4090 performance"?

comments.text:
as a very intelligent person who has gamed from about age 5 and im now 31, and ive gamed in competitive scenes coming close to winning fortnite cash cups. so im no pro but im pretty damn good. also i had a top 10 lap time in the world on wrc 9 after only about 10 lap attempts and turning the game off. easily could of grabbed #1 spot if i tried. i also was the first person i ever saw used the armadyl godsword to gmaul combo on runescape way back in 2009/10 as to name a few corny accomplishments here to prove me point. 

my experience with dlss and the amd/nvidia equivalent i forgot which one is which, i find that i can feel a ton of input lag and it makes me perform alot worse when i try to do anything in game like shoot, drift a car or hit the brakes on time etc. any software that runs on your pc will create lagg. dlss is a program. it runs it will take away from your input time and all its doing is lowering your resolution in game, when you can just do that manually yourself. i absolutely dont get it. its bs from people who dont know what gamers want. gaming is all about the feeling of interactively manipulating a scene or moving objects on a screen through peripherals. its about being apart of that world pretending you are in it through your own actions. and if those actions are slower, the sense of being in that world is diminished. adding software to give fake sense of higher frame rates will improve how many times your eye will see the world changing that you are manipulating, but also reduce the accuracy and affectiveness in which you can manipulate it. its counter productive and it makes zero sense. fake frame softwares are incredible for movies. i love it on my tv. in games in absolutely pointless. yes some people wont notice it mainly console gamers wont notice because they are used to being restricted to v sync and having their input times capped. so theres a huge market there for them to use their advancements in ai to sell to companies that make use of ai software and hit two birds with one stone and sell gamers ai cores to make fake frames at the same time. it shows a lack of care to us gamers as a customer base. and we are the ones that built their companies. of the backs of our sales they grew. now they push us aside. make cards for non gamers that use ai cores, give us gamers more real cores. simple. i urge anybody to go put a game on right now and play it with frame gen on, then turn it off and play, do it 5 times and really try to see the difference in how fast you can react to something with it on vs off. you wont want to use it again once you notice it. its like when you move from console to pc for the first time and you toggle off V SYNC  for the first time ever and you feel like you were robbed of gaming experiences this entire time.

comments.text: 5070 is a poor design and will never trump or even get close to a 4080 or 4090. The 5070ti is more on par as a true comparison, It's ridiculous to try and compare the two even if NVIDIA said it was supposed to get close to a 4080 or 4090. That was a simple marketing gimmick and people fell for it! being as fast as a 4080 or 4090, that simply wont happen on the shear fact that a 4090 uses a 384-bit bus rate which is how fast data transfers between the motherboard and the GPU. Any 192-bit GPU is trash, you only want to use 256-bit and above for GPU's. A good GPU product tester should know this and also take it into account! BTW if your struggling to run 1440p on any game, then you definitely need help, cause 1440p is now easily 1080p of 2025
comments.author: @JuiceDraticZ

comments.text: The bus width isn't as much of a determining factor in performance as it used to be. 192-bit and less is trash though...but it's not as all-important as it used to be.
comments.author: @steveliciousrex

comments.text: @steveliciousrex  obviously it is and it has always been a factor for every high-end GPU from either the 3070ti, 3080, 3090, 3090ti, 4070ti, 4080 4090 5070ti, 5080, and 5090 all use 256-bit 384-bit or 512-bit for a reason. They need to have that fast of data transfer rates for a reason and this is also what makes a GPU fast. No matter how you look at it.
comments.author: @JuiceDraticZ

comments.text: @ Not saying it's not a factor but bus sizes aren't increasing at all. The hardware and architecture behind them are hence the bus width isn't as important in determining final performance as it used to be. Thats all I was saying.

comments.text:
Just don't go into naming without mentioning the mobile stuff as well. Like look at the RTX5090. I ask you to spot the difference. Note that these are both sold as RTX5090:

Subj.A: ...................| Subj.B:
GB202 .................... | GB203
92200m transistor ....| 45600m transistor
512bit memory...... | 256bit
1790GB/s ................| 896GB/s
2017(2407MHz) .......| 990MHz (1515MHz)
21760 shaders .........| 10496 shaders
680 TensorCores ......| 328 TensorCores
170 RTCores............ | 82 RTCores
128MB L2 Cache...... | 64MB L2 Cache

Note that one does ~104.8TFlops, and one does 43.94Tflops. That's not even the same ballpark. And the main difference? The slower one is WAY more expensive. Because it's for laptops. That should NOT be called 5090, just like how this 5070 should NOT be compared to the 5070Ti.

comments.text:
You still need a solid base framerate of 60fps for FG to work nicely (and its actually really nice). The 4090 has significantly more raster to get to 60fps whereas the 5070 will need to cut corners to get there. The 4090 will have significantly better quality at 100-110fps over the 5070 at 200fps because for the 5070 to get 60fps, it requires much more aggressive upscaling and lower quality settings. I'll take 110fps at much better quality over doodoo quality at 200fps. The 5070 @ 30fps + 4x FG is a miserable experience and should not be compared to a 4090 @ 60fps + 2x FG.

It should be noted that the 4090 in this video is rendering NATIVELY, and using DLSS Quality + 2x FG will get you about 140-150fps (about the same as the 5070 with 4x fg, but it's a significantly better and smoother experience.) I'm not sure why Linus did that.

comments.text:
I wish we could go back to the GTX 900 series days, where the uplift over the previous generation was decent, the uplift between each card skew was plenty, and the prices (mostly) justified the performance... I remember when the GTX 980 Ti came out, it was all the rage. We had all thought that the 980 itself was just the best of the best (minus the GTX Titan X) and then the 980 Ti launched and everyone's jaws dropped.

Where the f*** is that excitement nowadays? Everything feels ridiculously soulless when it comes to new graphics card generation launches. The 9070/9070XT is probably the most excited I've been for a graphics card launch in years... And they didn't even announce a "high end" card this generation, and right now if you want something "higher end" you'd probably still have to go with the 7900XTX.

AMD should take this opportunity of seemingly stagnation in gen-to-gen performance increases with price hikes, like they did with Intel on their CPU market, and release a couple of high-end cards that match or exceed 5080/5090 at a lower price point. I think they have a real opportunity here to maybe become dominant over NVIDIA if they played their cards right. NVIDIA has been taking L's left and right for the last year or so.

comments.text:
8:45 "Nvidia has delivered on lots of pixels at high framerate"

I disagree tho. Nvidia is using fancy buzzwords and confusing acronyms to TRICK gamers into thinking they are getting a good experience. 
That card will be rendering games at 720p or less (not a lot of pixels is it?). And only 1/2 or even 1/4 of those frames will be genuine, killing latency in the process.

I'm only 26, but 15 years ago I remember I had to install Fraps to get FPS number in games and know how to adjust my settings accordingly to get a good experience. The media and channels like yours Linus were the ones that pushed so hard for gamers to pay attention to the fps counter that nowadays so many games come with fps counters baked in. Providing tools for gamers to know if they are getting a good experience, and I find that amazing.
Now Nvidia is abusing the trust that gamers have in the fps counter to trick them into a bigger fps number for a subpar experience.
You must now continue to educate gamers about internal resolution and frametime so that they learn that despite Nvidia's technologies being cool, innovative, and possibly good in the future. Right now Jensen is just adamant on lying about his products capabilities and that's just plain wrong.

comments.text:
​@ It's good. The only compatibility issues are with kernel level anti-cheat. 99.99% of games just work out of the box, and the games with normal (non-kernel) anti-cheat also just work (such as elden ring with easy anti-cheat). If you got Nvidia, you lose about 5% to 10% fps compared to windows, but if you got AMD, it's pretty much on par with windows if not better for some games.

For older games (from the windows 7 era and before), they actually work better on linux. On windows you have to install a bunch of GOG patches or community mods, when those games just run normally through WINE on Linux, without the patches.

All you have to do is install steam, and turn on proton compatibility for all games. Just makes sure you get a distro that is already pre-configured if you want it to "just work". If you install Arch for the memes, using your computer will become a full-time hobby

comments.text:
sooo... they basically pulled up the whole RTX 2070 problem all over again.

The 2070 used the TU106, which was also the chip used in the 2060 and 2060 Super, except it was fully unlocked. The 2070 Super on the other hand used the TU104 die, which is the same one used in teh 2080. Nvidia almost didn't even cut it down that much compared to the 2080 back then, so both cards were within a couple of % of each other, with the 2080 Super being a little boosted over the base 2080, pulling up a little bit more from the 2070 Super.

All of that would have been good if they were priced accordingly, but they weren't making the 2070 Super a considerably better value than both the 2070 and 2080 / 2080 Super, as it performed almost like a 80 class GPU, with a 70 class GPU price tag.

It seems Nvidia "kinda forgot" what a 70 class GPU is supposed to cost like with the 50 series, they priced the 5070Ti higher than cards like the 3080, which is nuts to me.

Yes its a big claim. Yes it's marketing. It heavily depending on the 4x frame gen but when I see Cyberpunk 2077 running 120 on my 5080 everything maxed out with path tracing and with an actually playable latency, I cannot stop smiling. If I got a 1600$ 4090 already I probably not going to buy a 50gen card. If I secured myself with a 5090 I probably will be more happier. Because I am not upgrading from 4080super, like a lot of the reviewers are comparing to. I upgraded from a 3080, which struggles at 2fps just to take a peak of the real capabilities of how good a video game can look. I am also excited to filter technology they are making such as neural face, and the neural shader texturing. Although these are not 50 series exclusive.

You have to realize for a lot of folks who didn't upgrade to 40 gen, the 50 series is not too bad, with the current price of 40 series on the market. If I am buying a new PC now, the 40 and 50 gen are all expensive and about same performance. The few 4070 super or 4070ti super are all 600$+ to 700$.

comments.text:
I'm a vaguely unique use case, I do a fair amount of gaming, but also some video editing, 4k 10bit 4:2:2 stuff that is a bit strenuous on my hardware.
My big issue is I need Vram for those video workloads. I've got a 3060 12gb and it does everything I want other than needing more vram. 16gb doesn't feel like enough.
The only current gen option for me is a 5090 to get more than 16gb vram.
I'd contemplate switching to AMD or honestly even Intel but thusfar the vram options there are no upgrade, and would be more like a shift to a different card that will perform similarly to my 3060, as I'd lose CUDA and some of the optimizations that Davinci Resolve has for Nvidia cards.

Dual 3060s? 3080? 3090? 4000 series options? 7900xtx? I'm not impressed with my options.

comments.text:
When the horrible performance of Dragons Dogma 2 and Monster Hunter Wilds forced me to use DLSS and Framegen to make it playable. I've become more accepting of these AI features. Especially now that I've tried DLSS 4 and FrameGen on my 3070 after a bit of tinkering. Although the flaws are still there, it allows me to play Dragon's Dogma 2 and Monster Hunter Wilds at respectable FPS (70-90), instead of sub 30fps with stuttering. FrameGen is a great way to get more longevity out of older cards! I still think adding anything more then 1 additional fake frame is bullshit and I cannot see how this makes things any better, but a single frame to "double" the fps is a remarkably great thing! Well, for games that doesn't require low response times or are of a competitive type. For Action-RPG or games less dependent on low-response times (i.e Souls games, Monster Hunter Wilds, Dragons dogma etc), FrameGen and DLSS is just phenomenal! 

But I would NOT recommend anyone buy a card for these features alone. I'm just saying that for most games and people, the flaws of these technologies aren't going to matter when you're actually playing. I'm for sure not noticing it when I'm playing but I can see the flaws if I take time to examine and look for it..

comments.text: It seems they Nvidia is  playing with the naming again.  Instead of looking at the number, we should probably compare price/performance by tiers.  Last gen, bottom tier was 4060 followed by 4070 then 4080 then 4090 with "ti" and "super" thrown in to push each tier to a higher performance level.   This year, bottom tier is 5070 followed by 5070 TI, then 5080 and 5090.   On that basis, the new bottom tier of 5070 is better than last gen bottom tier,  but way more expensive which it  appears is Nvidia's marketing plan; intentionally obfuscating the naming convention to demand higher pricing.

comments.text: Let’s be real… AI generated frames only work well if the real frames that serve as a sample are well generated. So if your gpu struggles with generating base frames below 60 fps, then AI will only reproduce and amplify the visual artifacts. And to generate real frames you need good hardware, which is difficult to assess when games are constantly demanding more processing power and some graphics card companies like to muddy the water with complicated names and far-fetched comparisons while playing the "how less can I sell for more” game with their customers…

comments.text:
The kind of DLSS does not change the FPS you get signifcantly, mostly image quality

DLSS is nothing else but reducing the resolution and then upscaling it back up with AI. As an example, DLSS balanced will only render 60% of your selected resolution. 

That is what saves FPS: That you only render 60% of the pixels. If you use a 60% render scale or DLSS quality, FPS is nearly identical (bit better with render scale, not much). If you are using DLSS 1.0, 2.0, 3.0 or 4.0, does not matter, FPS are mostly the same, it is the image quality that changes

Therefore even DLSS 5.0 won't change anything regarding FPS

comments.text:
​ @MayumiTheKimura  You say that now, but Nvidia got something going here. I've been programming for years, and I've done my fair share of research in the AI field. While at the moment, DLSS 4.0, is impressive, it's by no means a game changer, especially due to the limited support.

However, graphics cards have reached their limit. They won't really get better after this point. For generations we've made transistors smaller and smaller, and around 2008 we hit the stop. So the solution? Make them bigger, and add more transistors, etc. Problem is, that's also nearing it's end. So what's the solution? Fake frames.

With proper time and research given, DLSS has huge potential. While artifacts may be noticeable at 60 FPS gameplay, it certainly won't be once raw performance reaches 150 FPS. Especially not if it keeps improving at it's current rate.

So in reality, in a few years, (5 - 10 years). Nvidia will hit the end, and we will get a 8070 (random card guess), that can reach a minimum of 150 FPS in every game, 4k native. And once we've hit that DLSS will be good enough to upscale that into 500 + FPS, at which no more is needed.

comments.text:
@ And so what if frames aren't real? From the perspective of what matters, there 100% is a difference between rendered frames and AI interpolated frames.

I don't give a flying fuck as a game developer if the frames outputted by the game is real or not. What I DO care about is that the game renders frames, because there's calculations behind them, code that runs, input that is being checked.

Frame gen is just fancy interpolation. You could replace all the AI frames with a static black image and the game wouldn't care.

If you only had AI frames, you wouldn't be able to interact with it.
